docs.abstract: Number of calories is up by average of 21 in meals ordered by customers at fast food outlets in New York City since restaurants began posting calorie counts (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE INCREASE IN CALORIES IN MEALS ordered by customers at fast food outlets in New York City after restaurants began posting calorie counts of their menu offerings, according to a study in the journal Health Affairs. City officials hoped consumers would moderate their eating habits after a law took effect in July 2008 requiring restaurants to post calorie figures. The study of four fast food chains in poor neighborhoods with high rates of obesity found that meals ordered for lunch and dinner after the law went on the books had a mean of 846 calories -- up from 825 calories before the law.

headline.main: In New Jersey Race, Weighty Issues

docs.abstract: Has the race for governor of New Jersey really turned into a referendum on weight?
docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Times reporter David M. Halbfinger wrote about the latest developments in the New Jersey governor's race, pitting incumbent Jon Corzine against Republican Christopher Christie. Apparently, "You're fat!" is now a cutting-edge campaign tactic.
docs.snippet: Has the race for governor of New Jersey really turned into a referendum on weight?

docs.lead_paragraph: What better way to attune our leaders to the needs of their constituents without health insurance than to put them in the same position?
